subs.text: This place was rented
It was for organizing a concert.
Months before setting up the scene
hundreds of trucks started to come
No one was asking them
They were taking away
Historical artefacts,
Ceramics, pots,
They were loaded into the trucks
They took away everything from this place.
They turned this place upside down.
What did you feel during that time?
As you said, this is the hardest part.
If we ask it to talk about
I do not know how it would respond.
After all those things happened,
they left this place alone.
When I came here again to check it,
it was like it was in pain.
Tired of all the things it had endured.
It is in a position where it cannot talk
It was attacked from everywhere.
For me the walls are like a human,
When you try to hear their complaints
I cannot even imagine what you'll hear.
It is a deeply wounded structure.
After all those things happened
they blamed the city walls.
They prohibited the access of the public
Was it your fault that
This place, Seven Tower Dungeons,
Unfortunately, nowadays,
Since it was closed after all that.
I have the impression that
to be preserved for the times ahead
I hope that they will be more careful
And we can leave a better heritage
During my childhood, in the holiday mornings,
for example, if the Ramadan Holiday has three days,
on the mornings of the first day,
the second day and the third day,
we used to gather here all together
and ride around in a horse-drawn carriage.
The horse-drawn carriages used to be decorated.
We used to go upward that road.
Since we were all just kids,
we used to chant on the horse-drawn carriages.
What was it that we used to chant?
“Hindi baba hindi!”
Then the other group shouted back
all together:
“Hey yallah!”
<i>“Hindi baba bindi! Hey yallah!"
"Hindi baba arabadan indi. Hey yallah!”
We used to chant things like this.
We used to get on the horse-drawn carriages
and ride all day long
all over Edirnekapı.
and the neighborhood.
Whenever I come here
I remember the wonderful times
I spent with my friends,
and especially with my father.
This is one of the best places I spent time at as a kid.
Since my dad used to keep a pet goldfinch,
we used to bring the birdcage here.
My dad used to put the birdcage on the ground here,
so our goldfinch could sing with the wild goldfinches.
My dad used to bring me here
and we brought our goldfinch with us
so it could sing with the other goldfinches.
We used to stay here for hours.
Back then, there were no vehicle exhaust sounds,
no car sounds, no honking sounds.
There were only the sounds that the trees made.
There were nightingale sounds.
There were goldfinch sounds.
And of course,
there were the sounds made by
the horse-drawn carriages of our neighbors.
There were horses tethered
below, over there. So there were horse sounds.
As I have said, these are
the top three sounds that I can’t forget:
sounds of the trees,
sounds of the goldfinches,
and the sounds of the nightingales.
Those sounds were one the best aspects of the time
I have spent here.
I wish my street could talk.
I wish I could tell you about my childhood.
There were pedlars during my childhood.
The yogurt pedlar carried a long pole over his shoulders.
There was a wicker tray hung at each end of the pole
He placed the yogurt containers
in those trays and
he held a bell in one of his hands.
As he walked along the street,
he used to ring the hand-bell that went “jingle, jingle, jingle.”
We knew that the yogurt pedlar was coming
by the sound of his hand-bell.
And there was our postman.
Uncle İbrahim was our postman.
Postman Uncle İbrahim delivered our mail
for many years, and
we knew he was coming even before he arrived
by the sounds of the children.
When the kids saw postman Uncle İbrahim,
they used to sing the postman rhyme:
”Look! The postman is coming”
”And saluting everyone”
”Everybody watches him and wonders”
All the kids used to chant like that.
So this is the way,
how we knew that
Uncle İbrahim had entered the neighborhood
and he was coming to where we were.
Our watermelon pedlar used to chant:
“Honey sweet melons! Sugar sweet watermelons!”
I can neither forget those tastes,
nor those sounds
or the atmosphere we had.
All the pedlars brought their products
on horse-drawn carriages
or on barrows
or in wicker baskets hung on their backs
into our neighborhood
so that we did our shopping
from these people.
I wish we could go back in time to those days
so that I could tell you all about them and
you could live those times
and experience the tastes.
If we consider the sounds as music this place used to have,
first of all, there was entertainment here.
What kind of entertainment was there?
Sounds of goblet drums, violins,
Sounds… You could hear the sounds of
any instrument you can think of.
We used to listen to these sounds here
and cheer up and have fun.
And most of the people who visited here listened to these sounds.
People used to cheer up and feel happy as well.
Both in terms of culture and way of life,
this is a very different place. It has a history of a thousand years.
The sounds used to echo here.
All the sounds from the entertainment there
use to echo here.
Whether live music or
music from a cassette player,
or the sounds of children,
or the cheerful and lively sounds of people,
we used to hear them, but as I said,
we don’t hear those sounds anymore.
Back then,
during my childhood,
the wedding processions,
I mean the processions of the circumcision feasts,
arrived at Eyüpsultan from that direction.
On their way back from Eyüpsultan,
they came from that direction.
The boy who would be circumcised rode a horse
and his family followed him,
and they all walked from here down that street.
The processions included musicians and singers
and they all walked down here,
and sang at the same time.
How were the weddings organized here?
The weddings were very jovial here.
Usually,
everybody danced to Romani music.
The “çiftetelli” was favorite. It was very entertaining.
Back then,
we had a vegetable garden
in that area that you can see from here.
But now,
there are residential buildings there..
There used to be henna nights in that area.
A tent used to be pitched there.
Everybody in the neighborhood,
our families, mothers, sisters, siblings,
use to go to the henna nights over there.
They used to have fun.
The henna nights used to start early evenings and
continue until very late hours after midnight.
I remember something very clearly.
During the holidays
we used to decorate the horse carriages.
Or to put it correctly, the owners of the carriages decorated their carriages.
The carriages were decorated beautifully with ribbons and everything.
Even the horses used to have ornaments.
Everybody, the kids put on their best dresses.
All the children, boys and girls, got into the carriage.
There used to be 25 or 30 kids in the carriage at a time.
We wandered the whole neighborhood.
When it was time to get back to our street,
we all used to feel a little sad
because our time was up.
"We have been far and we are now back."
We used to sing on the way back.
Then we got off the carriage and the next group of kids got in it.
So it was done by turns.
Eh, what were the sounds we heard here?
For example, we don’t have the following anymore:
We don’t hear the nightingales in the trees.
There was the sound of goldfinches.
During the summer nights especially,
the crickets used to sing.
Just like we see in the movies,
the sounds of crickets filled the dark nights.
We can’t hear any of these sounds.
The sounds of goldfinches,
their songs can’t be heard anymore.
Also for the sounds of nightingales.
We can’t hear them anymore.
We had a “şıra” peddler and when he shouted “Şıracı!”
all the kids ran to where he was.
He used to give us grape juice.
We had a yogurt pedlar.
We don’t have those anymore.
We had a gum pedlar who used to sell pine resin.
He was an old man who had only one leg.
He used to come to our neighborhood.
He recited poems. Whenever he started reciting poems,
all the kids would start following him.
We used to run after him as well.
And he used to offer us a piece of gum.
I was asked to think of the Land Walls as people and ask them a question.
To tell you the truth,
when I think of the Land Walls, I am unable to be romantic.
I am unable to come up with romantic words or ideas.
That’s why the first question that comes to my mind is this:
After all these hundreds of years, and after all the civilizations
and the societies that have come and gone,
do you feel responsible or guilty or unsuccessful
due to the collapse of these civilizations and the emigration of societies?
The Land Walls exist to divide one part from the rest and to establish signs of dominion over an area.
They exist to protect a certain region.
We have talked about the Byzantines, the Ottomans,
and the people of Sulukule, but ironically none of them have been preserved.
None of them were able to survive to today. If the Land Walls were people,
I would really wonder what they felt about this.
I am asking the current walls because
they are at their oldest age right now. They get older every second as we speak.
Right now, they are at their wisest age since the time they were first built.
So it would be more logical to ask the current walls.
If the walls were people and they were to answer my question, what would they say?
Actually, I can’t really speculate. I guess they wouldn’t have looked at mistakes they might have made.
They wouldn’t have considered themselves guilty since they have been victims as well.
They were after all, created for this job. They are here to give a sense of authority, acceptance and possession of this land.
We are not talking about a castle, but about a huge peninsula, and it is surrounded with walls.
Aren’t the walls also big, tragic and primitive at the same time?
These kinds of borders are supposed to be symbolic.
The Berlin Wall wasn’t impassable but they built a wall there anyway.
This has had a tremendous effect on people.
I think that the Land Walls cause a similar effect in people's minds as well.
This may be the reason why the Land Walls have been unsuccessful in spite of being very protective of their interior.
You cannot protect anymore because the era has changed.
The times have changed.
You can’t protect anything with walls or iron railings anymore. There is no such defense system.
My first connection with Sulukule is this building.
My dad and my grandma lived together here after my granddad passed away.
After they moved here. my aunt got married.
She moved to a place a little further down the road.
This is the story of my being here. I mean, I live here as a result of my father and his family moving here.
Where are they from? They are from Malatya.
They moved from Malatya. What I told you happened when my dad was 13-14 years old.
This is the first place they came.
I don’t know what the circumstances were, but they didnt come here with too much eagerness or enthusiasm.
They choose this neighborhood because the rents were low here.
So they settled here.
After they bought a house. they became more attached to the area.
This coffee house has been here as long as I can recall.
There are people here right now.
There is an entombed saint here. I remember my mom and aunt praying each time we passed by here.
It was later revealed that these were ordinary people’s graves.
I don’t know why, but after that my mom and aunt stopped praying as we passed by here.
Nothing has much changed in these neighborhoods. They are basically the same. The urban transformation is taking place over there.
These three apartment buildings are interconnected to each other.
They are known as “blocks”.
Many of our relatives live here. My dad’s aunts, uncles, from both his mom’s and dad’s sides, all live here.
I grew up in the last apartment in the first block. That’s where I lived.
This building is new. This area used to be completely empty.
There was a huge area behind this building.
I remember that people sacrificed animals on that ground.
That area was used for sacrificing animals. Then the place became a garbage collection center.
All the collected garbage was dumped there.
It stayed as a garbage collection center for 2-3 years. It was removed following the urban transformation project.
And this building was built.
I wasn’t a kid who played in the street. I wasn’t allowed to go outside without an adult accompanying me.
This street was one of the centers of the area that is known as Sulukule.
There was a barn ahead and the weddings were held there during the summer.
This area was full of shanty houses.  This area here was too.
So… I could watch that barn from the balcony of our house because I wasn’t allowed to go out.
I went out by myself only once and I think it is a tragic story.
I swear to God, I don’t know... My mom, my aunt and my had gone to visit someone.
We were home alone, with my disabled cousin, who can’t walk
My cousin was a smoker and he had run out of cigarettes.
He wanted me to go to the grocery store to get him cigarettes, but
I had never been outside by myself before.
His request even had sounded very funny to me.
He insisted by saying, “C’mon, you can do it.”
"There is nothing to it."
That is the only time I went out by myself.
I was very excited and I remember that I ran all the way to the grocery shop.
There is a café there.
There was a grocery store where there is a café now.
I went there.
I bought a pack of cigarettes and came back.
Perhaps due to my strict upbringing, I don’t know,
but I thought I would be kidnapped and an organ harvestesting gang would steal my internal organs.
Lo and behold! I had never been outside and I wasn’t allowed to go out. When I got back to my apartment,
I realized that I'd forgot the keys. I didn’t have the keys with me and my cousin couldn’t open the door
because he was disabled.
We had a neighbor, Aunt Nezahat, who lived in the apartment below ours.
I took the spare key from her.
I don’t remember what kind of lie I told her but I took the spare key from her and got home.
I gave the cigarettes to my cousin but they were a wrong brand.
I had to go out again but this time I didn’t run.
My initial anxiety was over.
My aunts were interviewed as well and they all said that this place was so joyful.
They talked about the entertaining weddings organized here,
and the festive nature of this neighborhood.
But if you ask me,
that is a very hypocritical because
they never told me that and forced me
to spend my time
watching everything from our balcony.
I wasn’t allowed to play in the street.
I wasn’t allowed to go outside.
But they were having fun all this time.
That’s what they claimed, I don’t know.
How long did this continue?
It continued like that until I started elementary school.
That’s because after elementary school,
I went to another school in Bahçelievler.
So, I started living with my aunt only during the school holidays.
Even then my visits were short. Whenever I came home for a holiday, I used to see signs on the houses.
or some official papers were stuck to the doors.
During the next vacation i saw something different. Some streets were closed down or metal guard rails were put up.
What was I saying?
I came home from school to find guard rails all over the area.
It was a sign that there would be some construction there.
This transformation continued like this for 2-3 years.
I think people never did really believe that they would be forced to leave.
They never truly comprehended something like this might happen.
But it has one way or another happened.
I don’t know. I think this here was the place where the weddings took place.
Horses and all that stuff were here.
These parts were full of shanty houses, I remember.
As I said earlier, I walked on this streets by myself only once.
It is not that bad, according to what my mom and aunt said.
Didn’t you have any friends who lived here?
No, I didn’t. Oh, we had this neighbor.
Her name was Aunt Fatma. Her house is among the demolished ones.
She now lives in the inner parts of Karagümrük. She had a daughter.
Her name was Dilan, I think. She and I were friends.
But I spent most my childhood in our apartment. Unfortunately, I didn’t go out very often.
Is there any specific scent you remember about this neighborhood?
Horse smells!
I guess, this must be the first thing everybody said. I remember the horse smells.
Another thing I remember is that houses didn’t have doors.
Instead of a door there were curtains were the doors are supposed to be. Sometimes, the curtains were partially open or
I was close enough to the house to see inside.
It excited me so much to see the inside of a house. How do other people live? What do they do?
There certainly was an outdoor culture. I was someone who didn’t go outside but life here was in the street.
Everybody was outside day and night.
Even the elderly aunties didn’t stay inside and watch TV.
They used to sit in front of their doors and
eat sunflower seeds and chat with each other.
Or they had needles and threads in their hands and finished their handicrafts.
This may be the reason why my sense of watching and observation has developed too much.
This may be the reason why I have chosen motion pictures and television as my major because I constantly observe.
I constantly watch.
I knew that real life was in the street but I wasn’t allowed to go there.
This is the grocery store I was telling you about. There is a café in its place now.
As you see, there are guard rails.
Obviously the rails didn’t suffice so barbed-wire has been added.
This street was closed to traffic for a few months.
We couldn’t pass through here.
If we had to come here, we had to detour from the back.
It was shut down suddenly.
There is a wall here. There is another wall there.
This passage has been shut.
What are they protecting the people inside from? Or what is the problem out here?
I am unable to understand.
They distributed entry cards to the residents.
The residents of this apartment complex could enter only by showing these cards.
Anybody who didn’t have an entry card couldn’t get in.
Later, the guards started letting me in when I said that I lived at the Tuna Blocks.
But this part of the neighborhood was still off-limits for outsiders.
Then this practice was abolished. The residents gathered signatures and sent complaints to the municipality.
Seeing these parts of the neighborhood alienates me.
There is Okyanus College here now but what was here before?
People send their children here.
They may think that they are being protective of their children.
I wonder if the children here are taught anything about the history of this neighborhood.
Or does anybody say, “Before our school was built here, there were this and that here”?
I find all this very strange.
Another thing… It is also strange that…
What is usually done? Let’s say that I am a property owner.
If there is an urban transformation undertaken in my neighborhood, then they should at least give me an apartment in return for my property they demolished.
Following the completion of urban transformation, I should be allowed to come back and continue to reside in my neighborhood.
This has not been the case here.
“We are transforming this neighborhood.”
“We will give you an apartment in return for your real estate, but not here.” I find this practice very strange.
Even if I assume that this has been a transformation of social classes, I am not sure if it has been successful.
Something has certainly changed.
But strangely enough, this place has not become a place where “white Turks” live.
No matter how much they change this place, it is still where the immigrants live. The Syrian immigrants live here.
There are Koreans, which I don’t understand why.
You can even come across Pakistanis here.
I don’t know if it is the appeal or charm of this place but I think it is this neighborhood’s fate.
The area continues to be home of people who don’t have a sense of belonging here.
Or of people who couldn’t get their social identity accepted.
I don’t know.
On one of its walls, that house had a portrait of an old woman playing the goblet drum.
Whenever I saw that picture, I knew that we were close to home or getting far away from home.
We used to pass through here when we went to the metro station, and there is an entombed saint further down.
My relatives always stopped by that grave and said prayers.
I used to stand by them but I didn’t do anything.
I didn’t know what to do.
I was not able to perceive in any way what was holy about that grave.
Then one day when I was 13 or 14, someone asked me a question.
“Why aren’t you saying prayers?”
When somebody said, “Why don’t you come with us?” I had been already aware of some of the things.
I told them I didn’t belive in what they were doing and I wasn’t going to say prayers.
What is an intriguing fact is that after all the demolition and destruction in this neighborhood, the entombed saint is still there.
When I asked about how the Land Walls could be used these days, one of our neighbors said that
there would be an artificial pond and small rowing boats on this side of the Land Walls.
That neighbor claimed that since this area was very important, there should be canals and boats which would be similar to the ones in Venezia.
I think this was a strange idea that was thrown around during one of the women’s meetings.
The horse carriages and horses were kept here.
I guess this is where the horses were taken care of by their owners.
And during the Sacrifice Holiday, the animals were sacrificed here.
This was also the animal market.
Now, this place gets full of school buses during certain times of the day.
There used to be a playground here but it doesn’t exist anymore.
We walk around these parts very easily.
But...
I feel somewhat unlucky for not being able to live all this when I was a kid.
I live right in the center of everything but I am not aware of anything.
Nobody knows who I am in the neighborhood.
This is certainly strange.
That is perhaps the reason of my antipathy towards the Land Walls.
I don’t know. It is because my life is surrounded by walls.
There is a wall here.
There is a wall in my apartment.
There is a wall at home.
We are talking about the lack of preservation of the historical sites.
What I don’t understand is that despite our way of life, the route we have chosen,
and being overprotective as a society,
why are we so much unaware of our surroundings? Why hasn’t this awareness developed?
The apartment complex system has developed nowadays.
A young family would want a safe life that an apartment complex provides for their children.
As you can see, there is an urban transformation is taking place here and everywhere is surrounded with barbed-wire again.
It is so important to protect ourselves.
Protection may be considered as comfort but I think it is pathetic.
But, I don’t know why the awareness of preserving historical sites has not developed.
Perhaps, everything will get better if we can get rid of the instinct for self-preservation.
But I think that it may be too late.
Yes, these parts were not protected back then.
There were no barbed-wires in Sulukule when Romani people used to live here but
the street gangs existed anyway.
The street gangs are not peculiar to Romani people.
They still exist in Karagümrük.
You can’t enter certain parts of the neighborhood without their permission, or when the gangs realize that you are a stranger,
you may encounter a certain reaction.
This self-preservation has always existed.
But they exist to protect people from other people,
not from properties.
The people who live there provide these properties with sense of belonging anyway.
When we talk about sounds, the first thing that comes to my mind are horse sounds, just like the other participants.
Horse sounds are like a signature of this neighborhood. The main factor that makes horse sounds so distinctive
is the olfactory memory.
The horses exist in our memory not just by their sounds but they also have an unique smell.
I think that the most distinctive scent of this place was the smell of horses.
We are in the middle of the horse market right now. And I remember
horses running around here.
Over there...
This place belonged to the horses.
It is very clear. This is where they could run freely and this place was here because of them.
There were also places in the central part of the neighborhood where they had horses.
This is why I care about the horses, because in addition to being the most memorable sound,
the horses were among the most important factors that created our olfactory memory.
They were the fundamental sign of this neighborhood. We may even call them a symbol.
We are talking about an area here that is very suitable for playing football.
We are talking about the horses and about how they can run around freely here.
When all of these things that we talk about come together, they create a very beautiful painting.
Children used to play here.
People used to have picnics with their charcoal barbeques here. Barbeques were allowed for a period but then they were again prohibited.
There used to be a playground over there.
It was there until last year. There is no playground now.
There were these sounds, and also there is this sound of urbanization just next door.
I don’t know how enjoyable it was to have a picnic with all the vehicle sounds,
but the sound of those picnic goers were enough to change the atmosphere here.
The sound of entertainment came from inside the Land Walls.
There was an empty area next to where I lived.
When there was not an open-air wedding, there were animals out grazing.
Children also played there.
But when there was a wedding, which was nearly every other night during summer,
that area was used, and since my house was very close by,
the sounds of a wedding were the most prominent sounds for me.
Although I couldn’t see the area very clearly due to some buildings blocking my view,
that area was a point of great intrigue for me.
Maybe the saddest part for me is the loss of those sounds.
I would prefer to have those sounds ofthe weddings than any other sound that was lost.
I am very sad for losing those sounds,
that is because music is something that gives joy.
The people who live here make their living from making music.
They are professional musicians.
Their music was part of our way of life.
You didn’t have to be at the wedding to hear the music.
When you walked past this neighborhood or even when you went out on your balcony,
If there was a violin sound…
I remember these things. There was a fight one night.
Everybody was worried and wondered what the fight was about at that time of the night.
We learned the next day that there was someone playing the violin, and there was a man who didn’t want to listen to it.
We had such easy and beautiful problems back then.
Hello!
I’d like to write you a letter about the joy of your participation in a beautiful and meaningful project.
Questioning is one of the most important virtues of humans.
Since we all live with the philosophy of letting sleeping dogs lie,
we neither remember to question nor know how to question.
With the Land Walls on its both sides, my hometown Yedikule has a historical place like a church or a mosque in every corner.
I have always wondered
what these Land Walls, which have stood for centuries despite all the difficulties,
would have told us if they came to life?
Why were you built? How successful were the years in achieving your objectives?
What has changed around you while you have stood?
What was won or lost by whom?
When you look at the humanity what would you liked your objective to be?
The Land Walls answer:
The purpose of our building
is to protect the city, in other words, homes where people lived,
against the attacks which were made
as a requirement of the state
during the ancient times.
People have always lived around us
in one way or another and they continue to do so.
Now, I am asking: What is it that you are unable to share?
Don’t these Land Walls provide you with enough knowledge about past quests?
So many have come and gone. So many nations have perished. None of them exist anymore.
None of them are still alive. When the time comes, you’ll be gone, too.
Why do you insist on fighting and killing?
You are a human being, and isn’t the rest of your identity incidental? Raise your head up occasionally and look at the history.
Hey, human beings! Live and let live with compassion, and
love by cherishing our children and
not forgetting our elderlies.
Live humanly without saying you, I, or them.
My father took over the management of this pastry shop in 1961 where he'd worked as an employee.
He has struggled long battles. He has been through some very tough times
as he has fought against poverty and hardship,
He has managed to keep Emek Pastanesi going for 50 years.
We have worked as a family, my mom, my dad, my older brother and older sister. We have struggled together.
Later, my brother-in-law joined us and we have some good memories, of neighbors and friendships.
There was solidarity. We have some bad memories as well as good ones.
There used to be a problem with extortion of money back then.
It was very rare but nonetheless it happened.
May God rest her soul; my grandma interfered by saying, “Don’t do anything to my son.”
Despite those incidents, we have had very good friendships here and generally everything has been fine.
Sure, it was utterly different.
You have something that not everybody can have but we didn’t eat what was sold.
It was something we never knew.
We, as three siblings used to wait in front of our house,
hand in hand, for the pedlar
who sold pastry from a hand cart.
We were outside until midnight or 1 o’clock since everybody knew each other.
This one was a shanty house, so was this one with a yard which was built later.
Even this building… Hello! How are you?
I want to say something.
We put newspapers on the ground when we ate sunflower seeds
Then we collected the newspaper and the shells.
There were pistachio trees inside here.
There were nettle trees.
We still have fig trees.
It was an open space, anybody could get in.
We spent our childhood in there.
There was just a single family guarding the place.
That’s all. I mean, we didn’t leave the neighborhood much.
We played all our games here. For example?
We played hide-and-seek, tag, dodgeball and we played with marbles, which are unknown today.
Our mosque has been converted from what once was a wedding reception venue.
It is Uşşaki Camii. You should be able to see from here.
They say that there is an entombed saint inside but that is not true.
My mom says
Auntie Cahide lived in the next building which is now part of the mosque.
This coffee house, as I said earlier, belongs to Brother Okşin.
He used to manage the coffee house with his older brother.
We had Auntie Ganimet who was like a mother figure for the whole neighborhood.
She tried to help everybody with their problems and tried to teach right from wrong.
She was a very big woman and when she put her fist on the table everybody listened to her.
From here...
I don’t remember this part from my childhood.
My mom remembers the tramway.
We used to go to Aksaray and took a tramway from Aksaray to Eminönü but
those were electric tramways. Don’t get it wrong.
My mom remembers the original tramways here.
I remember the electric tramways.
We used to take electric tramways from Aksaray to Eminönü or Sultan Ahmet.
They were abolished later, too.
There were no cars around here.
We had only one.
We had Uncle Hasan who was a cab driver.
He gave rides to everybody.
There were horse carriages although not too many.
This is where Tunca Cinema was.
It had both summer and winter sections. You took the stairs down.
You took those stairs to get downstairs. The theater was behind this.
I mean both the summer and winter theaters were here.
We always had soda pop at the summer theater.
Everybody talked while watching a movie.
People used to comment on what they saw on the screen.
It was such fun.
It was something the neighborhood shared.
The movies changed twice a week and we tried to go twice a week.
It was something we all shared.
We were sharing something together.
The horse carriages followed this road on holidays.
The carriages were decorated, everybody got on and we rode all the way to where the castle gate is which we are now heading.
The Land Walls...
There were... what do you call them? Those big boats in the open fairground.
We used to ride those swinging or turning things, and had fun as children.
We could go there freely, without any adults accompanying us, and play.
But you can’t send your child anywhere today even if you want to.
You can’t take your eyes off of a child.
I sometimes think what could be the reason.
What has changed that made our country like this?
The bravado culture.
That disappeared after our youth.
When was that?
It was perhaps after the anarchy period.
Yes, it should be after the anarchy period. There were gangster types, or "rowdies" around during my childhood and the most famous one in our neighborhood was Brother Okşin.
His name was Ertuğrul. He managed the coffee house I showed you earlier.
He was one of the nicest people in the world.
His mother was Auntie Ganimet who I talked about; the woman who made everybody listen by putting her fist to the table.
The same thing was true for Brother Okşin.
He tried to help everyone with a problem.
It was as if he was responsible for everything that happened in the neighborhood.
He never discriminated. I am telling the truth, honest to God!
He wasn’t like today’s rowdies. He wasn’t based on being bad.
Each neighborhood has its own distinctive culture. He was part of our culture. I don’t know what adjective
I should use for him. It was as if he were responsible for everything.
This street goes up to our school.
Yedikule is known for its vegetable gardens. I don’t need to talk about Yedikule vegetable gardens. Everybody knows about them.
They are a continuation of something.
There is no other place that has cos lettuce like Yedikule has. It has a unique taste.
Then you saw that they built Yedikule Mansions where the vegetable gardens used to be.
They destroyed the history.
It's the same with what they did in Sulukule. Sulukule suffered the same thing.
They demolished Sulukule and built buildings similar to these.
We are moving by destroying history.
And we are continuing to destroy.
We neither learn from history nor attribute any importance to it.
We continue our lives as if it would not happen to us.
We bury our heads in the sand and continue to live by ignoring something.
We just continue our lives.
Yedikule Dungeons...
We grew up inside these.
This was a very popular movie stage.
We used to watch as they shot movies.
Just think about it; the entertainment in our childhood was watching movie sets.
We went there to watch. We saw famous actors such as Cüneyt Arkın and Kartal Tibet.
It was very different watching them as there was so much variety.
What we saw on those movie sets were very different for us.
Whenever I look at these walls, I always think. There had been fights on both sides of the wall.
And there had been so many fights. What had people endured? What fears and great things had they lived through?
What thoughts had they had? There have been those who said, "What is the purpose of this?"
There were those who said, "I am protecting my homeland?"
Some who came were scared.
Some had come out of some obligation.
There had been those who had died from the boiling oil poured on to them.
I always keep asking if all these were worth it.
While the Land Walls could have been built to keep the cold or the wild animals out…
Why did they need this?
What is the emotion within yourself that made you this way?
Can’t we tone these emotions down?
Can’t we manage to be humans? I still ask these questions and I will continue to do so.
But on the other hand, I also think something else.
How did they build these walls?
While the houses built today with plans and projects fall apart so easily, how did they manage to build the walls without so much knowledge, any plans or projects it?
They are still standing erect.
This is where Altınkapı is. Actually, this area hasn’t changed much.
They have renovated some parts but the entrance is the same as before.
These guard rails didn’t exist and we entered from there and used to have picnics close by Altınkapı.
It was on open grounds.
As I have said earlier, walking this way used to scare us because there was nothing here back then.
It really smelled around this way.
It was such a damp and dirty place.
Look, how beautiful this area is.
It is still beautiful but they have built something.
When they did something here…
They turned the inside area of Yedikule into a concert area for a period.
They used this area for car parking. They built a car park.
They put up street lamps where it was nice scenery.
Then some people started saying this about the concert area:
"There had been so many wars here.
Many people had died and had been buried here. Now, you are dancing on top of their graves.
Is this right? Is this logical?” These are all points of views.
Look, we can see the Land Walls better here.
Who knows who looked at the Land Walls from here?
What were their purposes?
What were their points of view?
Just think about it. They try to enter from here and do so many things to achieve that.
Cannons, guns, people…
It is important to be able to see.
I wonder if we are able to see. No, we are not.
We say that there were just a bunch of stones here.
We pass by here every day and we just look at these walls.
But we never think about what had happened inside.
These walls tell us so much. They tell us about our conflicts.
They tell about the international conflicts. They show power.
They say that they were here. They say that despite all has happened, something good would always stand.
They say that everything changed, depending on the point of view.
They say, "Look at me." They ask what we see. They tell us to think.
There hasn’t been enough maintenance because not enough importance has given.
Just like I said earlier…
The Land Walls are walls. They are steeped in history.
This is the common attitude because the mentality doesn’t exist.
Since that mentality is lacking, nobody has cared about the Land Walls.
As nobody showed any interest, the place was infested with weeds and everything else.
It was dark, damp and dirty everywhere.
Look, there is lighting now. There wasn’t any before and it was impossible to walk through here.
Nobody had to scare you about it; you'd soon get scared yourself when you saw the situation.
If you ask if this is still the case, I’d say a little.
People didn’t get around much back then.
People used to go only to certain places and stay in certain areas during my childhood years.
People usually didn’t leave their neighborhood very often. People who visited other places were small in numbers.
But now everyone goes everywhere and they see everything.
We would be amazed when we saw a tourist.
Foreigners knew back then but we didn’t.
This may be why we don’t have a fear of heights. This is what I sometimes think.
We were always on top of the Land Walls.
I remember how scared I was the first time I climbed those stairs.
There are no stair handrails or safety rails.
You are a child and very small and as you climb those stairs…
As a child those stairs are very high. There are no stair handrails.
I realized this as I climbed the stairs: How strong I am!
That thought occurs to you as a child.
You climb those stairs with those feelings. I just re-lived those moments.
In the beginning, you climb the stairs by staying very close to the walls.
As you get accustomed and realize what you can do, you start running up the stairs.
Then you whirl along the stairs.
If they asked me to do it again now, I couldn’t.
For example, we used to play "horses" on the walls.
Yes, and there was that.
We had make-believe wooden swords in our hands.
I guess I wasn’t brought up like a girl very much.
I used to play with marbles. I rode my bicycle and played with a toy sword.
I realize that I was a little bit of a different girl.
We played so many games.
Some played giaour soldiers.
That was what we were told.
What is a giaour soldier?
Usually we formed two groups.
That is the beauty of being a child.
You mmade two groups, and one group plays giaour soldiers and the other group plays Turkish soldiers.
You either used your toy sword or make-believe rifle.
I don’t know. You may pretend to ride a horse. We did whatever we imagined.
Lo and behold!
The giaour soldier didn’t have a specific thing.
The giaour soldier didn’t have a religion.
The Turkish soldier didn’t have a religion either because we just thought of them as Turks.
They were just Turkish soldiers.
It wasn’t as heated as it is today.
For example, we had Greek friends.
Yes, there was a certain thing towards the Greeks but only a few were like that.
Only some of the children were like that. Some much more than others.
They were Greeks after all.
We never had a “You are a Greek and I am a Turk” approach.
We never had such a fight. I don’t remember.
We didn’t live that kind of segregation.
These Land Walls had been built and then the outsiders had set up open markets
outside the walls to provide the needs of thoseinside.
This is how the vegetable gardening had been born.
It hasn’t been like this all the time. These grass areas were built recently.
They allowed them to be built.
This area has become a source of income.
You enter a completely different world when you get inside there, don’t you?
You weren’t able to pass through here this easily.
You had to walk very fast,
in a state of panic.
These parts were not like this.
There were no grass areas. Everywhere was covered with weed.
You couldn’t pass through and couldn’t get in. The area was infested by weeds. People made fires.
There were carcasses and a terrible smell.
The bottom of the walls weren’t visible.
That stairs weren’t visible. It was built later on anyways.
As I said earlier, when you went through here…
You moved fast to leave this part behind as soon as possible.
Look at the beauty of those birds.
We had yogurt pedlar who walked the whole neighborhood with a pole across his shoulders.
It had tubs attached that hung down. He walked with that and chanted “Yoğurtçiiii."
When he entered the street people would call.
The kids shouted "Uncle Yogurt Pedlar.”
They gathered around him with a plate; a bowl to be correct, in their hands.
Yogurt was cut very carefully; not watery. I repeat, yogurt was cut very carefully and put in a bowl.
This was his unit of measurement.
It was not sold by kilogram but by the spoonful. And it was a different kind of a spoon.
That’s how it was put in your bowl.
Following him, the milkman came.
We had our lemon pedlar.
He carried a round lemon tray on his back; no, not his back but on top of his head.
He used to walk barefoot and chant, "There is no water in these."
And he was barefoot.
He was a large and strong man.
He chanted “There is no water in these," as he walked the streets.
The sound of women sitting at their doorsteps…
As I said earlier, women usually sit at their doorsteps.
They had their needles and threads in their hands.
We, as children, played in front of our houses.
There was always noise in the street.
We all played from morning till midnight or 1 o’clock in the morning.
The things…
One of the sounds that we don’t hear anymore was...
Hello!
One of the sounds that we don’t hear anymore was...
On kandil nights we used to make…
There used to be small round tea boxes made out of tin and they were usually red.
We used to put a candle in this box and sing, “I sell butter…”
What was it? We shouted a rhyme: “Pay for the oil-lamp, it is night time,” and walked from door to door.
People put a lira, a dime or a nickel in the box.
There wasn’t a lira coin back then so they gave us 5 or 10 cents. We, as the neighborhood kids, collected money
and went to a grocery store to buy a pack of sunflower seeds.  We shared that money. There wasn’t "me" or "you".

subs.index: Depending on the season we either bought sunflower seeds or ice cream, or whatever…

subs.text: Is there another lost sound?
There is the sound of firecrackers.
We always played with fire crackers on holidays. Boy used to make noises with their toy guns.
“Girl chasers” were thrown to scare the girls.
Girls ran around screaming their hearts out until a mother’s shout was heard,
"Hist! Stop that this minute"
They were such beautiful days, as I remember them now.
We used to enjoy all those games.
Yes! Just imagine a group of 5-10 children all laughing
running towards us from around that corner on this street.
They aren’t there now.
Assyrian books, especially the ones about history, don’t say very nice things about the Byzantines.
The first...
Since I was brought up with history books, I enjoyed first hearing about the Conquest of İstanbul.
The history books and the television programmes
describe the Ottoman troops, prior to the breakthrough of the walls,
as if they were going to a wedding or expecting something nice to happen.
Did the people here feel the same way
as if there would be a wedding, the Turks would arrive, and they would rejoice together and have a good time?
What have the people here lived through after the Ottomans’ breakthrough of the walls?
Were they locked in their homes for days?
Could they go outside?
Could they attend their religious services?
Could they go to school?
Could they go for shopping?
I would like to ask my question to that section of the walls because my association is located just across it.
I see that section of the walls the most.
And we are in a very nice position side by side.
There are the towers.
This may be the most preserved and the most beautiful section of the walls.
I think that the wall would give a different answer than
what the history books and the television programs say.
As I would guess, and have seen in the movies,
when a place is being invaded by others,
the inhabitants will be frightened of the attackers.
The people under an attack will not welcome invaders
as if they were welcoming a football team.
I believe that the walls would give me the following answers.
People were locked in their homes for days.
They couldn’t go for shopping.
They couldn’t attend their religious services.
They couldn’t go to school.
And they lived through very difficult times.
This is my house. Actually, it is not mine, I am just a tenant.
I came here in 2009.
This is one of the first buildings that will collapse if there is an earthquake.
The building has large cracks in its walls, but I have to live here, and I do.
The Land Walls are visible from the back windows. There are also gardens out the back.
That’s the nicest thing about this building. I feel the fresh air coming inside when I open a window.
If I open a front window, all the smoke from the heating stoves in the neighborhood gets inside.
So I find it very special to breathe the air that comes from the gardens in the back.
Romani people live on the ground storey of my building.
There are Romani families across my building as well.
It was my third year in İstanbul when I moved here and I never knew what Romani was until I came here.
I learned about them here. Actually, they all live happy lives.
We work all day long and try to do our jobs but the money we earn is hardly enough for anything.
I mean, the money I earn doesn’t make me happy.
The Romanis may not make as much money as we do but they seem to be happier than we are. No, they don’t seem, they are happier.
My Romani neighbors made the spot across my building a meeting point.
They usually have friends visiting them. Actually, their crowd used to scare me in some ways. I liked how they enjoyed themselves but I was afraid to talk to them.
I was afraid of getting my house broken into or something.
They used to sit around and eat sunflower seed for hours. The seed shells formed small mounds on the ground.
One of the families had a daughter who used to whistle at me when I passed by them, but I couldn’t talk to her because I was too scared to talk to them.
I was flattered because a girl showed interest in me but I was scared even to look her way.
I don’t know why I was so scared of them; perhaps it was due to what people around me said about them.
Since this area is very close to Yedikule Animal Shelter, there are too many stray cats and dogs around here.
So I suggest you be careful around here. Especially, the dogs love to chase motorcycles.
They are very aggressive towards motorcycles for whatever reason. They even caused me to fall once over there.
I thought they were going to eat me but they ran away when I fell down.
I am actually a dog person but I had such an experience.
This is Yedikule Elementary School. We have 46 children at our immigrant aid society.
We received a notice from the District National Education Directorate. It said that we couldn’t use the aid society as a school.
And we had to enroll all the children at a school or a legal action would be taken against our organization.
I applied to this school to enroll our children.
There are 4 elementary schools in this district and I applied to all but I was unable to enroll the children.
The children couldn’t go to school for year.
We met someone at the District Directorate this year, and they sent an official letter to this school.
So, some of the Syrian children were reluctantly accepted by this school.
Yes, Turkey accepts the Syrian refugees and
boasts about welcoming 2 or 3 million Syrians.
But, what happens to all these refugees? Are they provided with anything?
We can’t even get the children enrolled at public schools. What would those children do?
Nobody gives decent jobs to the Syrians.
Anybody who can’t get job would look for alternative solutions.
Then we talk about how terrible the Syrians are.
We let them come but don’t provide for them. They live under bad conditions due to lack of job opportunities.
Then we curse them.
This is how it is right now.
But I was able to enroll 7-8 children at this school one way or another.
This is Hacı Evhaddin Bathhouse.
Hacı Evhaddin Bathhouse is the first Turkish baths I ever went to.
This is a famous bathhouse.
I didn't come from a bathhouse culture but I have been here.
And I first saw what a Turkish bath is here.
It is not too bad.
It is actually a very old establishment.
It may not be very hygienic for my standards.
Nonetheless, I enjoyed the experience.
When I was a student, our house didn’t have enough hot water.
For example, when I took a bath I used to turn off the hot water while I shampooed my hair.
So, I would not run out of hot water before I was done.
But when I came here, I could stay under hot water as long as I wanted.
I really enjoyed doing that.
I walked on the Land Walls a few times, too.
During one of those times, I came across some guys with a paint thinner addiction.
They asked for cigarettes, and when I couldn’t give them any they hassled me.
Since that incident, I have never been on the walls.
Otherwise it is very nice to walk on the walls.
But it is also somewhat dangerous.
See, some kids are walking there right now.
Since it was shorter and straight, it was more practical to take this road when I went to church or school.
But I didn’t want to walk this way because weed-smokers or paint-thinner addicts usually hung out here.
But during the day time, I sometimes take this route.
This is a nice and a straight street.
We also used to take this street when we took the children ice-skating.
If you compare this street to the ones within the neighborhood,
this street is easier to walk on. We used to have the kids race each other.
Who could run the fastest up to where that car is and back?
I really like this street,
but only during the day time.
I have witnessed the demolition of some shanty houses here.
Actually, not too many things have changed.
But they have started to demolish the shanty houses in Yedikule as well.
They are forcing the locals to move away.
They have done the same here.
There were many shanty houses here.
Now there is the Yedikule Konakları complex where the shanty houses used to be.
You can’t see any children playing inside the Yedikule Konakları complex.
Everybody lives inside.
Although the complex is well protected, nobody leaves their houses.
It is a luxurious place but there are no children around.
You can see the complex a little from here.
If it were a shanty town, the place would have been swarming with children.
Look at that place over there. It looks like a countryside village.
If the shanty town weren’t removed, there would have been a countryside village in the middle of İstanbul.
It looks abandoned now.
According to the elders, most of the houses demolished over there were wooden houses.
There are very few of them left.
But in their neglected condition, they still look more beautiful than the concrete buildings do.
The wooden house owners are unable to get permission to build new houses.
That is because their houses are considered as historical buildings.
What I hear is that the cost of restoring these houses to make them habitable is very high.
So, the property owners set fire to their houses and make it look like an accident.
When the house is burned down they apply for a construction permit.
And they put a new building where the wooden house once stood.
I have witnessed some of these things happening to wooden houses.
As far as I remember, it is very beautiful.
The famous vegetable gardens of Yedikule look something like this.
They produce very fresh vegetables. Whenever I pass by here on my way home,
I make sure to buy my greens here.
When people try to open up a space for their gardens,
they remove the stones from the wall to make room.
This practice of stone removal certainly damages the walls.
But people are not aware of what damage they cause.
Of course it is easy to talk about it but perhaps I may have done the same,
if I had to make an area for a garden.
To be honest, I used to get very excited when I talked about the Land Walls prior to coming to İstanbul.
Unfortunately, only the sections close to the gates and
some specific parts of the walls are restored, and the rest are a wreck.
I hadn’t known that the Land Walls of İstanbul were in ruins.
I find it very saddening to see one of the greatest and the most important symbols of İstanbul in such conditions,
as if they are not part of the history of this country.
Normally, Syriac history doesn’t say very nice things about the Byzantines.
That is because Byzantine is dyophysitic and we are monophysitic.
So, the Syriac church was under constant oppression. Since I was brought up in a monastery, I have read about that oppression.
I have read about what happened, what the king had ordered.
How we were oppressed by the Byzantines.
There weren’t many nice things about the Byzantines.
So, I wasn’t really very fond of the Byzantines.
I would have liked very much the grandchildren of the Byzantines to be still here in İstanbul.
Very few of them are left here and it is nearly impossible to meet them.
I have been here in İstanbul since 2007 but I have met only 3 or 4 Greeks.
I wonder why this important symbol of the city is not preserved.
Is it because the walls are part of the Byzantine history?
I don’t know. There is a restoration going on with every mosque that I see.
But I see no working scaffold which is erected for restoration at any church or at a section of the walls.
This saddens me deeply.
There are cemeteries starting from here on this side of the walls all the way to Edirnekapı.
There are Syriac and Armenian cemeteries in Mevlanakapı.
Erbakan’s grave is there, too, and it is visible from the road.
We celebrate the second day of our holiday at the cemetery.
I think it is the Easter.
The celebrations on the first day are for the living and for the dead on the second day.
These are very beautiful celebrations because the cemetery becomes a meeting point for many families.
People do not visit each other’s homes as much as the people in Mardin do.
People usually visit the homes of their relatives or close family members.
But everybody sees everybody at the cemetery.
It is a beautiful tradition.
This is where our aid society is located.
We have very good relations with our neighbors here.
They were a little uneasy when we first established the society and
when they saw the Syrian children arriving.
They may hear me talking now.
They asked questions such as why the children were brought here, why we couldn’t find any other place to take the children.
When they realized that we were harmless people and
we also offered certain services to the local children as well,
they started to approach us, and we now have very good relations.
This neighborhood may be considered as the slums.
The rents are low here. Although after the arrival of the Syrians the prices went up a little.
That’s why the locals don’t really like the Syrians very much.
That is mostly because the property owners want the locals to leave the neighborhood
so that the foreigners can rent apartments at higher rates.
It wasn't like this in the beginning. The Syrians preferred these parts because of this neighborhood’s proximity to the other parts of the city.
This area is close to Aksaray. Most of the refugees that come here usually try to go to Europe through illegal channels.
The people who take refugees to Europe illegally are based in Aksaray.
This neighborhood is very close to Aksaray.
That is one of the reasons the Syrians prefer to come here.
We are also responsible in a way for the change in the neighborhood by establishing the aid society.
People who saw what we offer let their relatives know. They called their friends and they called their own friends.
There is a public park here called Yedikule Park.
But now everybody calls the park the "Syrians’ park",
because the foreigners love to spend time at this park.
Actually, I live in a beautiful and romantic neighborhood.
I sometimes say that I live here because this poor neighborhood is the slums.
It is really a beautiful place.
Perhaps there are some people in İstanbul
who are jealous of me
because I live in a neighborhood with a view of the Land Walls.
I like it here. I am happy to be here. At least there are no concrete buildings across my window.
There are the Land Walls on one side and a park on the other side. This is a beautiful place.
This has been the Syriac Christians’ for 25 years. We have been using this church for the last 25 years.
Before that, we shared a church with the Armenians.
This is a Latin Catholic church.
This church was empty.
During the time when we shared a church with the Armenians, we encountered small problems such as delayed services because the Armenians finished theirs late.
This church was empty.
We asked the Assyrian Catholic Church if we could use this church.
They said OK.
It was a ruinous church anyway.
The Assyrian Catholic Church asked us only to take good care of the church and nothing else. We fixed it as good as we could.
We have been using this church for 25 years. The children attend choir and Syriac language classes here every Saturday.
Syriac families in Samatya, Yedikule and Kocamustafapaşa send their children here every Saturday.
The children also play games here and spend time together.
In addition to that, as I said earlier, they attend choir and Syriac language classes.
As far as I know, this steeple used to be concrete.
I am not sure but it was either intentionally destroyed or collapsed by itself because of an earthquake or old age.
This church is located very close to the railways.
So, the Christian French and British soldiers had rebuilt the steeple
with the rails they took from the railways.
I think that a steeple made out of an iron frame is a very rare thing.
I have never seen a similar steeple anywhere else.
That is the sexton’s house.
The Christian Syrian refugees stayed there for some time.
That building next to the church is the cultural saloon. People gather there after the services
and drink tea or coffee and chat.
Or the place is used for banquets after christening and wedding ceremonies.
This is a very important place for socializing.
That is the train station up there,
When I was a student I didn’t have too much money.
So, I had to get on the train surreptitiously most of the time.
I think that it was this one.
Is there another one? No, there isn’t.
I broke this part of the railing a couple of times by dislodging it.
I tried to get inside from here to go to the train station.
But I was caught by the train conductor a few times.
Sometimes, I was told to go back,
and sometimes I was told it was okay.
Then I found some sort of a solution.
As the train approached from that direction, the conductor usually stood where the turnstiles were.
I waited the train to pass me. As soon as the train slowed in front of the station, I ran for the last railcar.
By the time the conductor could reach to the last railcar, the train was moving again. I hopped a train this way so many times.
Well, this is usually the way of the paint-thinner addicts to board a train.
The paint-thinner addicts use this way to hop on a train as well.
One time, as I was running towards the last railcar, I saw the conductor coming towards me.
I moved my hand to my face, as the paint-thinner addicts do when they inhale.
The conductor saw what I did and turned back, and went back to the station.
If I hadn't made that hand movement, he would have probably caught me and made me go back.
I remember, I hopped on a train here for four years.
I remember those days whenever I walk by here.
The railcars were very old and the heating system didn’t work.
We would freeze until we arrived at Küçükçekmece.
The doors of the railcars didn’t work properly. The ones that worked were always ajar.
But that train was a life saver.
It was always crammed with people.
This is the beginning of Bucakbaşı Street.
I lived here for almost two years in that half-stone/half-wooden house.
It has a beautiful, 400-metre square back yard.
I had a happy and a tranquil life here.
I lived in peace here.
Then this street was opened to one-way traffic.
It has become noisy.
It has lost the tranquility that it once had.
This house was used for the personnel of İsmet Sungur Bey's mansion.

As we exit through the gate, a shrine waits for us.
This is actually a manmade structure and a fake shrine. There is no one buried here.
It was built during the years of my childhood as a symbolic structure.
The story of this fake shrine is this:
There was a big tavern managed by Rums a little further down from here.
The clientele of that tavern had used this spot to relieve themselves as they left.
The proprietors of the tavern wanted to prevent people from doing that.
So, late at night, they brought some stones and arranged them to resemble a shrine.
They put a candle inside and lit it, as if someone holy had been buried there.
As time passes, strangers who don’t know the real story make wows and light candles and so on, thinking that it is a real shrine.
Then the municipality got involved.
And their involvement is based on hearsay. It even says on this sign: “According to rumour, Wise Yusuf is buried here.”
The historians could have researched and recorded what is really here.
There is a real shrine here but that one isn’t named and dated like this fake one.
There is a shrine over there at the back.
And that shrine is thought to belong to a holy person from one of the eras of the modifications.
But there is no one buried under this fake one.
It is just a made up one.

The history text books we used in middle and high school mention something that is called “Rum liquid.”
This liquid was used in the moat to reinforce the defense of the city.
What had been called “Rum liquid” back then is actually petroleum, which hadn’t then been discovered.
Petroleum floats on the surface of the water and burns.
It was used as a part of the defense here.
These are the moats. They were filled with water back then.

Stork’s Nest Mosque...
Hacıevhaddin Mosque is built by the Architect Sinan.
Someone from the family, known as Debbağzade, had commissioned this Stork’s Nest Mosque.
The mosque’s architectural plans were found in a building in Karagümrük.
But I had a small part in the rehabilitation story of this mosque.
I found an epigraph here during the reconstitution of the area, which was just an empty lot back then.
There were some scripts in old Turkish on the epigraph.
I called Professor Ferudun Özgümüş.
I said, “Dear Hodja, I found something here. Can you take a look at it?”
We turned the epigraph over and took pictures of the scripts. The hodja took the pictures to the university to get it translated.
It turned out that the epigraph belonged to Stork’s Nest Mosque.
There were also a few tombstones from the special cemetery section of the mosque.
So it was determined from the epigraph and the tombstones that there had been a mosque there.
Then some documents were found which stated that the original rehabilitation of the mosque was sponsored by one of the Architect Sinan’s relatives.
Later, the mosque was rebuilt on the same spot, according to its original plan.
So this is how Stork’s Nest Mosque, from which we now hear the adzhan, came back to life at that spot, 100 metres from here.
