That street over there became one of my favorite streets
after I reached a certain age, because it is called Emek [Labor] Street.
The Workers’ Blocks are located on that street.
Since they are in the Walled City, they became one of the most expensive properties here.
Their owners ask for astronomical figures.
That is because they are detached houses with trees between them, and they all face a garden.
Although their rooms are considerably small,
they are two storey houses.
There isn’t any other similar housing anywhere else in İstanbul.
In addition to planting a tree or flowers wherever there is empty space,
another tradition of the Walled City is stray cats.
People always take care of the stray cats in the Walled City. Always!
The cats never go hungry here.
It is such a tradition that when a cat starts hanging around a shop,
the owner of that shop starts taking care of that cat.
The house which was rebuilt correctly…
…is that 19th century house over there.
It is now in a very good condition.
It was renovated so it stood up again.
There are similar houses next to it.
Those aren’t renovated so they can give you an idea…
…as to what this one once looked like.
Do you see those four houses?
They can be turned into beautiful houses if they are renovated, too.
For example, that building is also very old. It looks like an apartment building.
These are French-style buildings built in the 1920s and the 1930s.
They all have balconets.
There are a lot of such buildings all over Fatih district.
There were many of them in Yedikule but…
…most of them are gone now.
Thank God, the Council of Monuments have registered these buildings...
…as examples of civil architecture and historical buildings. They can’t be demolished anymore.
It is okay to renovate them but they can’t be changed.
But there is one great problem we see in Fatih district and…
…that is the illegal storey additions. This house is actually…
…a three-storey building but it has another storey added illegally.
This is one of the biggest problems we have.
That castle or the fortress we see up ahead was built…
…by the Sultan Mehmed the Conqueror in the second half of the 15th century.
The importance of that castle is that it protects a gate, a monument from the Byzantine era.
It is the Golden Gate. Bu we can’t get inside.
I’ll show it to you from the outside.
There was a fountain here.
We didn’t have running water in our houses back then.
So people carried water in buckets to their houses from the fountains.
These fountains have no function anymore.
Because every house has running water nowadays.
That castle or the fortress used to be Yedikule Museum.
It is this structure that gives Yedikule its name because it has seven towers.
Or it supposedly had seven towers.
Because it has six towers today, not seven.
Two of these six towers were built in the Byzantine era.
Oh, pardon me! Three towers were built in that era.
Two of the towers are located by the most important monument of the late Roman Empire.
It is the Golden Gate. I’ll show it from the outside.
As far as I know, there is no entry here.
They don’t allow visitors inside.
We’ll go that way and make a turn over there.
If you look in that direction where the towers are…
or where the Yedikule Museum used to be...
…you can see that the towers are octagonal.
All the towers have one thing in common.
They hflare out towards the bottom.
The purpose is to have a strong static standing posture.
The towers went through a very heavy restoration in 1958.
The dentils or the crenels you now see were all added…
…during the restoration in 1958.
It was an elaborate restoration. The gate was rebuilt almost from scratch.
The gate had been in a really bad condition.
The octagonal tower also served as a prison.
Whoever the Ottoman Empire was at war with…
…that nation’s ambassador was imprisoned in that tower.
I remember how this neighborhood was.
I was born and raised here.
We used to have a museum.
It was one of our cultural attractions.
We had theatres: one for summer and one for winter.
And almost every day…
No, not almost but actually every day…
the mobile library visited us. I don’t know if you know what that is.
You may not know since you are very young.
The visits of the mobile library…
…provided library services to the people.
You took a book and returned it when you were done reading.
Then you took another book.
There were bank branches here. The public transportation was easy.
There was the train and also we had public buses.
Now, none of those exist.
They have removed the train and cancelled the bus routes.
You have to take either a taxi or a shared taxi now.
The mobile library doesn’t come to us anymore.
The museum is closed down.
And Yedikule used to be a lot cleaner neighborhood.
The streets weren’t as dirty as they are today.
Sometimes I think that Yedikule was like a place in Europe.
It used to resemble the developed places of Western Europe.
But it is a lot worse place.
This is very unfortunate.
Let’s go that way.
This has survived in a good condition until today.
This is a non-functioning fountain.
These fountains are gradually disappearing all over İstanbul.
But thank God, there is a book now.
A book that catalogues all the fountains, authored by [İbrahim Hilmi] Tanışık.
He has recorded and catalogued all the fountains…
…that date back to the Ottoman era.
But these fountains don’t serve any purpose anymore.
This is the mosque’s entrance.
The name of this mosque is quite interesting: Kürkçübaşı Hüseyin Ağa.
This is something that goes back a very long time.
Perhaps this guy was a leather trader.
There were leather workshops here in the past.
They were here even during the Byzantine era.
There were slaughterhouses here during the Byzantine era.
Animals were slaughtered and
skinned here for leather manufacturing.
The same trade continued here during the Ottoman period.
Thus most of the Ottomans who lived here were in the leather trade.
This is one of those tradesman: Kürkçübaşı Hacı Hüseyin Ağa.
This mosque perhaps dates back to those times.
There are other mosques with leather tradesmen’s names in the neighborhood.
These people had commissioned mosque constructions for good and praiseworthy deeds.
This tradition of leather manufacturing still continues today.
You can see leather shops and workplaces in Zeytinburnu and Kazlıçeşme.
I am repeating:
This is a custom that dates back to the Byzantine period.
When the Ottomans came here following the conquest…
…they found shops that are called “salhane”...
…in and around Yedikule.
“Salhane” means slaughterhouse. That is where animals are skinned.
The Ottomans didn’t interfere with the trade and let it continue.
The Ottoman Empire had such a practice, which was commendable.
They didn’t interfere with the local way of life and customs.
They let people live their lives as they did prior to the conquest.
So if you come across a traditional group of tradesman anywhere in İstanbul…
…that trade probably dates all the way back to the Byzantine period.
Let me give you a more interesting example.
You must have heard of the Covered Bazaar in Beyazıt?
It must be the continuation of a custom since the reign of the Roman Empire.
There was a place on the Markos Embolos and…
…it was part of a forum, which means a marketplace.
Thus, the Covered Bazaar has been here as a shopping centre since the 4th century.
If you look into that street, you can see the newly-built, large houses called Yedikule Konakları.
Until recently, there were cos lettuce gardens where those houses are now.
The cos lettuce of Yedikule is well known.
Or it used to be well known because it doesn’t exist anymore.
There were Rums and Armenians.
Most of the grocery store owners were Rums.
I can show you one of them.
There was a grocery store called "Zoto" over there.
The supermarket concept didn’t exist back then.
Zoto sold everything.
If you wanted something very rare or…
…something top quality, you needed to go to Zoto.
Something intrigued me as a child at Zoto.
The owner of Zoto himself never dealt with the customers.
There were clerks that helped the customers while the owner just sat behind the cash register.
It was a strange grocery store in that respect.
He died in 1984.
And there was a Rum poultryman called Tanaş.
He kept live chicken in his store.
When you needed to buy a chicken, you went to Tanaş.
And Tanaş would pick one of the chickens and slaughter it on his lap in front of you.
He wore a white, plastic apron that reached his ankles.
He used to slaughter a chicken on his lap, clean it and sell it to you.
Those chickens laid eggs in their cages as well.
So you could also buy fresh eggs from him.
He died, too.
There aren’t any of them left. There isn't actually anybody left.
We now have car-wash places like that one.
They didn’t leave. They died.
They passed away.
The migration was in 1974…
…during the Cyprus Operation.
Most of our Rum neighbours left during that war.
They might have felt unsafe and left.
The ones that I'm talking about didn’t leave. They passed away here.
There used to be wooden houses in that park’s place.
They all burned down.
Nothing is left.
Why did they burn down?
Almost all wooden houses burned down.
Yedikule is known for its house fires.
We grew up watching houses burn down.
There were so many fires in Yedikule.
I grew up in a wooden house.
As a kid I thought that our house, too, would burn down one day.
Because all the houses that burned down were wooden houses.
That’s why I have a fear of fire.
Thank God our house didn’t burn down.
But we lost many houses to fires in Yedikule.
Very few wooden houses are left and one of them is where I live.
We have had a sad incident here. Actually, we have had two.
These are incidents that have happened recently.
One is that latest gap we opened in the walls, 700 years after the conquest.
We recently managed that.
There was a wall in that gap’s place.
I don’t know who did that.
They literally broke down the wall and made a passage.
It may have occurred in 2007 or 2008.
We don’t know…
…who is responsible but we can make an educated guess.
This is not something a single person could do.
No single person would dare to come here with a pickaxe and a shovel…
…and try to open a gap in the wall. That’s not probable.
So, that ruin you see over there is new.
The second incident is that void square on the wall.
There was an eagle symbol of the Byzantine Empire dating back to the 5th century.
It has been there for centuries since the conquest.
During the propaganda period of the 2009 elections…
…political parties hung their placards everywhere.
When the placards were taken down, the marble eagle motif was gone, too.
We don’t know where it is now.
It was stolen.
Steeling that piece of marble wasn’t an easy task.
The marble piece was at least this thick.
You can see its dimensions on the wall.
So it is not something that you can grab and leave with under your arm.
You need a ladder to reach up there.
You need to dismantle it from where it was.
So it means that this was a coordinated job.
It was a job that required support from some places.
I was a member of the Council of Monuments at that time.
So I wrote a report about the theft to the Ministry of Culture and Tourism.
You can find images of the stolen piece on the internet.
You just need to search “stolen eagle from Yedikule.”
You may add that image to this documentary…
…and say that this symbol isn’t where it used to be.
It was stolen in 2009.
For example, that vehicle is not permitted to go through there but it does.
I don’t know which know-it-all is responsible for this but…
…two janissary statues are placed there.
What do they mean? Why were they put there? It doesn’t make any sense.
If they symbolize the courage of the conquerors or the janissaries guarding the city…
…they should have been put on the other side of the gate.
But they face the inside of the walls.
They have put these foolish statues here, and until very recently there was a watermelon pedlar by one of them.
It was as if the janissary was selling watermelons.
They finally woke up to the situation and had the pedlar move somewhere else.
This is the Golden Gate. The walls continue right and left from here. Those two marble-covered, quadrilateral towers stand on both sides of the Golden Gate.
It is a Roman triumphal arch.
Most probably, that’s what I think; it was built…
…in the 4th century, during the reign of Theodoros I.
Theodoros II had the walls built around it.
In other words, Theodoros II, who was the grandson of Theodoros I, had the walls built.
But that gate itself is from the second half of the 4th century, during the reign of Theodoros I.
It is a very interesting structure.
It must be a Kangal.
Has it waited for the last moment to notice us?
This is a moat.
If you look around you can still find cannonballs that were fired at the walls by the Ottomans.
The canons I showed you earlier.
There are many cannonballs lying around here.
These walls, which were built around the triumphal arch, are divided into three parts.
They are the Land Walls, the Sea Walls and the Golden Horn Walls.
Among these three sections, the Land Walls were the strongest and those who've had the most repair and attention.
That is mostly because the most vulnerable part is the land side.
It was easier for the attacking forces to manoeuvre on the land side.
That manoeuvrability wasn’t possible in the sea.
When the sea filled the coast line then the Sea Wall was demolished and a new one was built.
Therefore the Sea Walls and the Golden Horn Walls don’t belong to the 5th century.
They are younger because they were reconstructed several times.
They always followed the sea. There is this difference among the walls.
This is one of the most beautiful examples of military architecture from the 5th century.
The emperor entered the city here.
There is an ancient road that starts here and it is called Via Egnatia.
The name of the road changes to Messes once it enters the city.
It goes all the way to Sultanahmet and reaches the Million Stone in front of Hagia Sophia.
It splits into two sections.
Some textbooks claim that the Million Stone is the start of this ancient road.
And some textbooks claim that, “Yes, the road starts there but the stone’s got nothing to do with it.”
“That stone is part of a temple’s ruins.”
I agree with the latter.
But as I’ve said, we are able follow this ancient road from here all the way to Albania.
This is the best example of military architecture from the Middle Ages.
You are in front of an incredible monument right now.
Belonging to the 5th century, this military architecture…
has survived all this time despite all the damage and the earthquakes.
It wasn’t the Turks who caused the decay of the walls.
The Turks repaired the walls.
Despite all the earthquakes throughout the ages…
…the walls have survived until today, since the 5th century.
And I commend something here.
There is something called an aesthetic of ruins, isn’t there?
If we were to renovate these walls in Disneyland fashion…
…they would have looked terrible, of which we will soon see a sample.
I don’t like that appearance.
It is better to have the walls as they are.
But they must be conserved and preserved.
Unfortunately, the other side has gone through a heavy restoration and has lost its characteristics.
The restoration they have done may or may not be pleasing to the eye.
But it has been done correctly!
Why is it correct? Because the project complies with the restoration guidelines of the Council of Monuments.
I don’t think it is right to assess the restoration project as incorrect.
It is not right to judge without understanding the facts.
There are so many ignorant people.
It is something else to say, “I don’t like the way the restored section looks, it is not pleasing to the eye.”
But the project is not incorrect. It is done correctly according to the Council’s resolutions.
It has been a complete reproduction.
As I said earlier, it has become like something out of Disneyland.
I hope to God that they don’t repeat the same with the rest of the walls.
There are voices that I miss. I miss my mom’s voice.
I miss my mom and dad’s voices…
The train’s…
We don’t have the sound from the theatre anymore.
It doesn’t exist anymore.
What else…? In our neighbourhood and
in the other neighbourhoods on the outskirts of town,
there used to be yogurt pedlars. Do you know those?
They used to ring hand-bells. They don’t exist anymore.
Among all these sounds, the one I miss the most is…
…probably the sound of the train, because every time a train passed by…
…the glass on our sideboard used to vibrate.
That is all nostalgia that is stuck in my mind.
That doesn’t exist anymore.
But I should add something on that subject.
The train station in Yedikule was…
both a manufacturing facility and a repair shop.
There used to be a red locomotive there.
It was used to move train carriages from one place to another.
It worked all day long.
So the sound it made was disturbing to those who lived close to the station.
It was a disturbing sound because it had an oil engine.
But we were a little bit far away from the station.
We still are.
So that sound didn’t bother us, but it doesn’t exist anymore either.
That station is gone now and I don’t know what they’ll do with that area.
We are afraid that they may build buildings there.
We hope to God that that won’t be the case.
That railroad was built in 1826…
…during Sultan Abdülaziz's reign.
The train stations were also built during the same period.
I have had an interesting observation some time ago.
I was in Switzerland two years ago.
There is a town called Neuchâtel.
You may have heard of it. It is located next to Lake Neuchâtel.
When I was in that town, I had the surprise of my life because it resembled Yedikule.
All the train stations in Yedikule and
the lodging buildings for the engineers,
and the other personnel
were built by the French. They are all French made.
Neuchâtel is also heavily influenced by the French.
And it looked almost the same as Yedikule. The buildings looked very much like our buildings.
I was very surprised to see that resemblance.
But the buildings here are now all empty, abandoned, ruined and left to their fate.
I don’t know what will become of them.
We are at the farthest edge of Yedikule and in an area adjacent to the dungeons.
In other words, we are at Yedikule Gate.
That is a good question.
I would like to ask a question that arises from my genes and is to do with my own history.
And that question is:
If I had such an opportunity…
…I would ask the walls to go back to the conquest period, to the exact days of the conquest.
I would ask the walls to imagine this:
Let’s assume the walls are a mother...
…and the people are her children.
How does she endure this loss?
She has to keep on living because…
…she is still standing and she has to live these feelings.
I would like to ask her mostly about these feelings.
How can you still remain standing despite all that has happened?
When I think of my childhood years…
I remember that I spent a lot of time here because our relatives lived here.
I had relatives, especially my aunt who lived by the church here.
So they were people we visited frequently.
There is a distinct sound I remember from my childhood.
And that is the sound of the marketplaces, which were always set up next to the vegetable gardens..
I remember the sounds of the stallholders.
They used to sell fruits and vegetables, which they grew in their own gardens.
I miss that hustle and bustle. It doesn’t exist anymore. It is over!
The second loss is from my own culture…
…and that is the sound of the church bells
Of course, our community was a lot bigger back then.
There are many churches around here which are in close proximity of each other…
…and they would all ring their bells at every morning and evening service.
The absence of those sounds today is a reality.
I moved to Yedikule in 2010 after I got married.
I lived here for almost four years.
Those who don’t know this region may find this area interesting.
But it is really a special place and quite different from all other parts of İstanbul.
This neighbourhood is essentially a huge countryside village.
This is a place where people still know and greet each other.
The tradesmen here are really old-established.
The residents have been living here for a long time.
Yedikule is really a very unique region.
Nothing much changes here.
The people embrace their neighbourhood really affectionately.
The tradesmen, the residents, the neighbours have lived here for a long time.
You don’t see many newcomers here.
Instead of newcomers, you come across those who had once moved away but then returned.
Yedikule has this kind of an addictive characteristic.
It never lets you go.
You may leave but it always cals you back.
Here, the tradesmen and the residents are the same kind of people.
Nobody has moved away from here for the last 10 years.
On the contrary, there have been those who returned here. I have witnessed that.
I moved to Bakırköy but I am still very much involved with this neighbourhood.
That is because I am the clergyman of the church here.
It is the St. Constantine Greek Orthodox Church located in Yedikule area of Fatih district in İstanbul.
It is one of the largest churches of this district, even of İstanbul.
It is the largest church of the Orthodox community in terms of square metres.
It is a church which was built to serve the Karamanlides…
…who were brought to İstanbul from Anatolia back in the Ottoman era.
It has been the church of Saint Theodore from Stoudios Monastery to St. Constantine Church.
The monastery is dedicated to him because he once lived here.
This church is where the biggest iconography of its time…
…had been done during the Byzantine era.
Many of the famous church musical pieces of the Byzantine era…
…had been notated and performed for the first time here.
This is one of the typical Rum streets that is full of small houses, as you can see.
Most of these are wooden houses, but many of them have been fixed with mortar in time.
They all have the classical bay windows.
If you look closely, you can see that they are actually wooden houses.
The train ceased operation in 2015.
Yes, it was 2015 for this area.
In further back areas such as Bakırköy, it ceased to operate earlier.
We were able to take advantage of the train…
…in our region until 2015.
We were able to hear that sound very easily from our office and from inside our church.
As you can see, we are located close to the station anyway.
We used to hear that beautiful sound of the steam trumpet every 10 or 15 minutes.
Yes, there are parts that are currently going under urban transformation in Yedikule but...
You know, they have built something called Yedikule Konakları, which is supposedly an urban transformation. It is a disaster!
It is located just next to the walls.
I don’t know how much damage that project caused but the biggest damage that is visible to the naked eye is…
…the part that was knocked down to let traffic through, which we’ll see shortly.
It was a destruction that hurt in one's heart.
It was a senseless destruction.
I really don’t know the reason behind it but it is a idiotic destruction.
The main damage was done here.
This wall used to be complete in one piece.
There was just a small gap here on the wall.

Before that, it had been busy like a main road.
Here is an example for you!
What’s up, buddy? Are you recording me?
That was a very good example.
What would I like to ask the walls?
What would the walls tell me, convey to me?
My grandpa opened up a coffeehouse, a tavern by these walls.
My grandma worked in the kitchen, preparing chips and mezes.
Their children worked as waiters.
Two or three oddballs - quote unquote - "crazies"…
…had helped them.
Can the walls, the stones of the walls, tell me about my grandpa?
I never met my grandpa.
Would the walls tell me about my grandpa?
What kind of a man was my grandpa?
How did he live?
What did he talk about?
What made him happy?
What made him sad?
How did he talk to his clientele?
What did he talk about with his clientele?
Many different kinds of people had come here.
They were tradesmen, labourers.
They were Rum gardeners who worked at cos lettuce gardens of Yedikule.
They were Albanians who worked there, helping the gardeners.
They were police officers, nightmen.
They were workers.
They were bosses of the leather factories in Zeytinburnu.
They were doctors from the hospital.
What did my grandpa talk about with these people, what did he discuss with them?
He had been a Barba Vasilis type of a saloon keeper.
He used to circulate among the tables with his rakı glass in his hand.
I wish these walls, these Yedikule walls, could talk.
I wish the walls could have recorded everything…
…like we are recording this right now…
…so I could have listened to the walls’ recordings over and over.
I am waiting for the stones.
I don’t know. Perhaps one day…
They may talk.
The sound of Romaic!
Romaic was spoken.
I used to enjoy listening to Romaic.
It doesn’t have the musicality as much as French does, but…
…nonetheless, it does have some to a certain degree.
I wish Romanic was spoken as frequently as it used to be.
I miss hearing that.
But it is not something that can be gotten back. It is impossible.
I used to go to Surp Hovhannes Church in Narlıkapı
My uncle’s son, Hazoros Tomasyon…
He was a choir member.
He, my uncle’s son Hazoros, sang hymns beautifully.
Although we live in another part of the city…
…when we have a wedding or a funeral, we come to Narlıkapı Church.
We had our wedding ceremony, our children’s christenings…
…and my dad’s funeral at Narlıkapı Church.
Narlıkapı is an inseparable part of my childhood.
The sea used to reach the wall of Narlıkapı Gate.
The current coastal road didn’t exist back then.
During winter days, when a strong southwester blew …
…the windows and the stone walls of the church were hit by the waves with forceful blows.
That sound of the sea…
That sound of the wind…
And the sounds of the hymns would blend.
Those were very emotional moments, but they can’t be experienced anymore.
Those moments were really moving with the southwesters.
The hymns were sung beautifully on every Sunday, but…
…when the sounds of the southwesters and the sea
…something magical happened!
I was born in Yedikule, in 1949.
My name is Yetvart. My last name is Tomasyan.
My grandpa had come here very young.
The Surp Pırgiç Armenian Hospital is here as you exit the Yedikule Gate.
He worked at the hospital’s bakery as a bread maker.
Then he moved here when he had become a young man.
Over there, he opened up a place which had been something between a coffeehouse and a tavern.
That’s because this point was like a junction back then, as it is today.
The tramcars from Sirkeci, Bahçekapı and Aksaray came here.
This gate was the last station on the tramcars’ routes.
The commuters got out here.
There used to be phaetons here waiting for fares in a single file.
People got on phaetons to go to Balıklı Rum Hospital…
…Armenian Hospital or other places in that direction.
My grandpa ran his place until 1944.
Then the Wealth Tax Act came.
He had three sons and there was also himself.
The taxation for four men was very heavy.
This tax was applied to the minorities.
He was forced to sell the place.
He also sold two houses which were inside Yedikule area.
One of the houses was located closer to Samatya.
They paid the tax to avoid being deported to Aşkale.
Safa {\i1}Meyhanesi{\i0}
This is the only one left.
We didn’t use to come here.
I come here nowadays.
I have started coming here recently.
I usually went to Blind Agop’s or Minas’s places.
But there is no {\i1}meyhane{\i0} left either.
Today’s places can’t be called {\i1}meyhane{\i0}.
A {\i1}meyhane{\i0} was something else for me during my youth.
I am 70 years old now.
If I went to a {\i1}meyhane{\i0} for the first time when I was 20, that means I am talking about 50 years ago.
There is a huge difference between today and back then.
A {\i1}meyhane{\i0} is supposed to be a place where…
…you gather with your friends and have long conversations.
Today the waiters fuss over you so that you will eat, drink and be gone as soon as possible.
This is the street where I was born.
It goes all the way down to Yedikule train station.
I was born on this street.
That place in the corner…
We are in the İmrahor quarter. This is Zoto’s grocery store.
This place used to be a grocery store.
The shopkeeper was Albanian and his name was Zoto.
He used to provide the neighbourhood with whatever was needed.
There weren’t 40 different biscuit brands back then. There were maybe only two.
He sold everything from bread to kerosene or rice.
He had everything that a household may need.
There weren’t four or five or 10 different types of rice. There was a single sack.
There were two Rum madams living upstairs.
Zoto was their tenant, supposedly, but they lived together.
So, Zoto and the Rum madams were constantly…
…the topic of never-ending gossip in the neighbourhood.
We are close. I was born there.
But they have changed the façade.
They have completely changed the house’s façade.
The house remained in its original condition until 10 years ago.
A Rum family used to live here.
The man of the family was the production manager at the famous Hacı Bekir Confectioners.
I was born in this house.
My granny lived on the ground floor.
My Uncle Sarkis and his family lived in the middle storey.
We lived on the top floor.
We are at the end of  the Gençağa Street.

There was Auntie Kalyo there.
She used to call to me. I was just 10. She used to say, “Cutey! Cutey! Ela, here! Ela!”
“What is it, Auntie?” I used to say. She'd say, "Ela, here!" and I'd go.
She'd give me a glass of water, feed me a piece of patty and some dessert, and then would say, “Go and play now.”
That’s how it was. We had a nice childhood.
Let me tell you how they sent me to my military service.

They banged on the tin cans to send me off.
It was like this:
I was just about to get on the train, there was a whistle.
It was such a bittersweet sound that
It was such a whistle.
I was just getting on the train, I suddenly turned around and

Everybody started to laugh.

The sound its engine made, “Voooom! Gyyyyt!” It was great!
Would those sounds be forgotten?
I used to decorate my horse carriage beautifully with bay leaves.
I used to take children around for a ride.
I used to take them around for 10 cents, 5 cents, back then.
The children would clap, sing and dance in the back of the carriage.
The horse-driven carriage would move along the streets.
For example, I used to sell vegetables from the horse carriage when I was 12 years old.

Everybody knew what time I would pass through their street.

They walked by, ringing, 'ding-a-ling, ding-a-ling'.

Hey, magnificent City Walls!

how was it?
How was it when that hailed commander passed through here

or why do I want to ask this question
here at this gate?
As I said earlier, in 1453,
Mehmet the Conqueror passed through here.

you have seen the history being lived and you have seen many beautiful things
You have seen terrible things, too. Surely, you have seen everything.

The reason that
I am asking this question is this:
